column1: Today's cancer treatments help cure many children of cancer.
Late effects are treatment side effects that appear several months or years after treatment for cancer.
Whether your child will have late effects depends on the type of cancer and the treatments your child has.
The medicines used for chemotherapy and the high-energy rays used in radiation therapy can harm healthy cells.
Radiation therapy has a more direct effect on long-term growth than chemotherapy.
The following are examples of some late effects based on body parts affected.

Brain: - Learning - Memory - Attention - Language - Behavior problems - Seizures, headaches Ears: - Hearing loss - Ringing in the ears - Dizziness Eyes: - Vision problems - Dry eyes - Watery eyes - Light sensitivity - Irritation (feels like something is in the eye) - Drooping eyelid - Eyelid tumors Lungs: - Lungs cannot hold as much air - Shortness of breath - Cough - Trouble breathing - Increased risk of lung infections - Increased risk for lung cancer Mouth: - Small or missing teeth - Risk of cavities - Sensitive teeth - Delayed tooth development - Gum disease - Increased saliva or dry mouth Other late effects may include: - Muscle or bone can be affected in any area of the body where treatments were needed.
- The heart's rhythm or function may be affected by certain treatments.
The Children's Oncology Group (COG) creates guidelines for long-term follow up in children and adolescents who have had cancer.
